RT @MAAlcala Hello. It has been nearly 5 months since I took over as the Chair of the @vademocrats Latinos. 

Maybe you‚Äôve heard, but we‚Äôve been a little busy. 

Here is a quick update: [THREAD]

RT @NateSilver538 Pew had some good data on this last year. About ~10% of Republicans left the GOP between late '15 and early '17. Of those, only *16%* approve of Trump. Another ~10% of former Rs waver back and forth on if they identify as GOP and they're lukewarm on Trump. http://www.people-press.org/2017/05/17/partisan-identification-is-sticky-but-about-10-switched-parties-over-the-past-year/ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Di0ZrUfXoAISjhN.jpg

RT @NateSilver538 Basically, the headlines about Trump approval being super high among Republicans imply there are a core group of voters who *never* desert Trump. But that isn't necessarily the case. Party identification is fluid. Trump approvers will join the party; disapprovers will leave.

To be clear, H.R. 6124 does not mandate Social Security coverage ‚Äì it merely ensures tribes have the ability to make their own decision.

Did you know that state and local governments were initially excluded from Social Security, but over time the law was changed to provide state and local govs the choice to extend Social Security coverage to their employees?
